kja6j8p6Text: Jacobsen PL et al. 2015b1
kja6j8p7Text:
A randomised, double-blind study of Brintellix® vs. escilatopram on sexual functioning
in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) experiencing treatment-emergent
sexual dysfunction.
kja6j8p8Text:
Study objective: Compare the effects of Brintellix® vs. escitalopram on sexual functioning in
adults with well-treated major depressive disorder experiencing SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.
kja6j8p9Text:
Key inclusion criteria
Men or women aged 18–55 years
kja6j8paText:
On a stable (at least eight weeks) SSRI treatment
regimen for a major depressive episode (MDE)
kja6j8pbText:
Treated with, and responding to, monotherapy with
citalopram, paroxetine, or sertraline
kja6j8pcText: CGI-S scores of 3 or less at screening and baseline visits
kja6j8pdText:
Sexually active at least every two weeks before onset of
the current MDE and/or SSRI use and experiencing
symptoms of sexual dysfunction attributed to
current SSRI treatment
kja6j8peText:
Total score of 41 or less for women and 47 or
less for men on the CSFQ-14
kja6j8pkText:
MDE, major depressive episode; CSFQ-14, Change in Sexual Functioning Questionnaire Short-Form; MADRS, Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale; CGI, Clinical
Global Impression; POMS-brief, Profile of Mood States brief form.
kja6j8plText:
Primary outcome: Change from baseline in the CSFQ-
14 total score after eight weeks of treatment.
kja6j8pmText:
Secondary outcomes: The MADRS, CGI, and POMS-brief were
used to assess antidepressant efficacy. Safety was assessed via
adverse events, vital signs, electrocardiograms, laboratory values,
weight, and physical examination findings.
Brintellix_871e32a93e: 1. Jacobsen PL et al. J Sex Med 2015;12:2036–2048.
